episode_summary: This episode covers a range of quirky and historical topics, including the unauthorized release of beavers into British waterways, the peculiar chair of a 17th-century Spanish ambassador, the Canadian Mounties' unique method of dealing with nudists, and a pivotal moment in statistical analysis history involving a tea-tasting experiment.

facts.fact: The unauthorized release of beavers into British waterways is known as beaver bombing.
In the 1600s, the Spanish ambassador to England had a specially made chair with a hole in the bottom to accommodate his anal fistula.
In 1930s Canada, the Mounties dealt with illegal nudists by covering them in itching powder.
The world of statistical analysis was changed forever because of a woman called Dr. Myriel Bristol, who is most famous for being able to tell whether a cup of tea was poured milk first or tea first.
